    • Method Detail

      • getAllKnownOptions

        public static SOCGameOptionSet getAllKnownOptions()
        Create and return a set of the Known Options.

        Before v2.4.50 this method was SOCGameOption.initAllOptions().

        Current known options:

        • PL Maximum # players (2-6) - default 4
        • PLB Use 6-player board* - default false
        • PLP 6-player board: Can Special Build only if 5 or 6 players in game* - default false
        • SBL Use sea board layout (has a large, varying max size) - default false
        • RD Robber can't return to the desert - default false
        • N7 Roll no 7s during first # rounds - default false, 7 rounds
        • N7C Roll no 7s until a city is built - default false
        • BC Break up clumps of # or more same-type ports/hexes - default 4
        • NT No trading allowed - default false
        • VP Victory points (10-15) - default 10
        • _SC Game Scenario (optional groups of rules; see SOCScenario)
        • _BHW Board height and width, if not default, for SOCBoardLarge: 0xRRCC. Used only at client, for board size received in JoinGame message from server to pass through SOCGame constructor into SOCBoard factory
        * Grouping: PLB, PLP are 3 characters, not 2, and the first 2 characters match an existing option. So in NewGameOptionsFrame, they appear on the lines following the PL option in client version 1.1.13 and above.

        Current Game Scenario options:

        • _SC_SANY SVP to settle in any new land area: SOCPlayerEvent.SVP_SETTLED_ANY_NEW_LANDAREA
        • _SC_SEAC 2 SVP each time settle in another new land area: SOCPlayerEvent.SVP_SETTLED_EACH_NEW_LANDAREA
        • _SC_FOG A hex has been revealed from behind fog: SOCGameEvent.SGE_FOG_HEX_REVEALED: See SOCScenario.K_SC_FOG
        • _SC_0RVP No VP for longest road / longest trade route
        • _SC_3IP Third initial settlement and road/ship placement
        • _SC_CLVI Cloth trade with neutral villages: See SOCScenario.K_SC_CLVI
        • _SC_FTRI The Forgotten Tribe: See SOCScenario.K_SC_FTRI
        • _SC_PIRI Pirate Islands and fortresses: See SOCScenario.K_SC_PIRI
        • _SC_WOND Wonders: See SOCScenario.K_SC_WOND

        Options for quick tests/prototyping:

        For quick tests or prototyping, including third-party bot/AI/client development, there are a few predefined but unused game options available:
        • _EXT_BOT Extra option for robot development
        • _EXT_CLI Extra option for client development
        • _EXT_GAM Extra option for game development
        These can be used to easily send config or debug settings to your bot or client when it joins a game, by setting a default value at the server's command line or properties file.

        If you want to add a game option:

        • Choose an unused unique name key: for example, "PL" for "max players". All in-game code uses these key strings to query and change game option settings; only a very few places use SOCGameOption objects, and you won't need to adjust those places. The list of already-used key names is here within getAllKnownOptions.

          If your option is useful only for developers or in other special situations, and should normally be hidden from clients, define it as an Inactive Option by using the SOCGameOption.FLAG_INACTIVE_HIDDEN flag.

          If you're forking JSettlers or developing a third-party client, server, or bot, any game options you add should use '3' as the second character of their name key: "_3", "T3", etc. Use SOCGameOption.FLAG_3RD_PARTY when specifying your options; see its javadoc for details.

          If your option supports a SOCScenario, its name should start with "_SC_" and it should have a constant name field here (like SOCGameOptionSet.K_SC_3IP) with a short descriptive javadoc. Link in javadoc to the SOCScenario field and add it to the list above. Because name starts with "_SC_", constructor will automatically call setClientFeature(SOCFeatureSet.CLIENT_SEA_BOARD). If you need a different client feature instead, or none, call that setter afterwards.

        • Decide which option type your option will be (boolean, enumerated, int+bool, etc.), and its default value. Typically the default will let the game behave as it did before the option existed (for example, the "max players" default is 4). Its default value on your own server can be changed at runtime.
        • Decide if all client versions can use your option. Typically, if the option requires server changes but not any client changes, all clients can use it. (For example, "N7" for "roll no 7s early in the game" works with any client because dice rolls are done at the server.)
        • Create the option by calling opt.put here in getAllKnownOptions. Use the current version for the "last modified" field.
        • Add the new option's description to the gameopt.* section of server/strings/toClient_*.properties to be sent to clients if needed.
        • If only some values of the option will require client changes, also update SOCGameOption.getMinVersion(Map). (For example, if "PL"'s value is 5 or 6, a new client would be needed to display that many players at once, but 2 - 4 can use any client version.)
          If this is the case and your option type is SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUM or SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUMBOOL, also update SOCGameOption.getMaxEnumValueForVersion(String, int). Otherwise, update #getMaxIntValueForVersion(String, int).
        • If the new option can be used by old clients by changing the values of other related options when game options are sent to those versions, add code to SOCGameOption.getMinVersion(Map).
          For example, the boolean "PLB" can force use of the 6-player board in versions 1.1.08 - 1.1.12 by changing "PL"'s value to 5 or 6.
        • Within SOCGame, don't add any object fields due to the new option; instead call SOCGame.isGameOptionDefined(String), SOCGame.getGameOptionIntValue(String), etc. Look for game methods where game behavior changes with the new option, and adjust those.
        • Check the server and clients for places which must check for the new option. Typically these will be the places which call the game methods affected.
          • SOCServer is the server class, see its "handle" methods for network messages
          • SOCPlayerClient is the graphical client
          • SOCRobotClient and SOCRobotBrain.run() together handle the robot client messages
          • SOCDisplaylessPlayerClient is the foundation for the robot client, and handles some of its messages
          Some options don't need any code at the robot; for example, the robot doesn't care about the maximum number of players in a game, because the server tells the robot when to join a game.

          Some options need code only in the SOCGame constructor.

        • To find other places which may possibly need an update from your new option, search the entire source tree for this marker: // NEW_OPTION
          This would include places like SOCRobotParameters.copyIfOptionChanged(SOCGameOptionSet) which ignore most, but not all, game options.
        • If the new option adds new game/player/board fields or piece types which aren't currently in SavedGameModel:
          • Either add the fields there, and test to make sure SAVEGAME/LOADGAME handles their data properly
          • Or, check for and reject the new option in SavedGameModel.checkCanSave(SOCGame) and SavedGameModel.checkCanLoad(SOCGameOptionSet); add a TODO to later add support to SavedGameModel

        If you want to change a game option (in a later version):

        Typical changes to a game option would be:
        • Add new values to an SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUM enumerated option; they must be added to the end of the list
        • Change the maximum or minimum permitted values for an SOCGameOption.OTYPE_INT integer option
        • Change the default value, although this can also be done at runtime on the command line
        • Change the value at the server based on other options' values
        Things you can't change about an option, because inconsistencies would occur:
        • name key
        • SOCGameOption.optType
        • SOCVersionedItem.minVersion
        • SOCGameOption.optFlags such as SOCGameOption.FLAG_DROP_IF_UNUSED: Newly defined flags could maybe be added, if old versions can safely ignore them, but a flag can't be removed from an option in a later version.
        • For SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUM and SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUMBOOL, you can't remove options or change the meaning of current ones, because this would mean that the option's intValue (sent over the network) would mean different things to different-versioned clients in the game.

        To make the change:

        • Change the option here in getAllKnownOptions; change the "last modified" field to the current game version. Otherwise the server can't tell the client what has changed about the option.
        • If new values require a newer minimum client version, add code to SOCGameOption.getMinVersion(Map).
        • If adding a new enum value for SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUM and SOCGameOption.OTYPE_ENUMBOOL, add code to SOCGameOption.getMaxEnumValueForVersion(String, int).
        • If increasing the maximum value of an int-valued parameter, and the new maximum requires a certain version, add code to SOCGameOption.getMaxIntValueForVersion(String, int). For example, versions below 1.1.08 limit "max players" to 4.
        • Search the entire source tree for its key name, to find places which may need an update.
        • Consider if any other places listed above (for add) need adjustment.

        If you want to remove or obsolete a game option (in a later version):

        Please think twice beforehand; breaking compatibility with older clients shouldn't be done without a very good reason. That said, the server is authoritative on options. If an option isn't in its Known Options set (from when it called this getAllKnownOptions() method), the client won't be allowed to ask for it. Any obsolete options should be kept around as commented-out code.
        Returns:
        a fresh copy of the "known" options, with their hardcoded default values. Includes all defined options, including those with SOCGameOption.FLAG_INACTIVE_HIDDEN or SOCGameOption.FLAG_3RD_PARTY.
        Since:
        1.1.07
        See Also:
        SOCGameOptionSet.getKnownOption(String, boolean), SOCGameOptionSet.addKnownOption(SOCGameOption), SOCServerScenario.cloneAllKnownScenarios()
